enums.name: FileState

values.name: uploaded
values.doc:
The file has been uploaded but it's not yet processed. This state is not returned by Azure OpenAI and exposed only for
compatibility. It can be categorized as an inactive state.

values.name: pending
values.doc: The operation was created and is not queued to be processed in the future. It can be categorized as an inactive state.

values.name: running
values.doc: The operation has started to be processed. It can be categorized as an active state.

values.name: processed
values.doc: The operation has successfully processed and is ready for consumption. It can be categorized as a terminal state.

values.name: error
values.doc: The operation has completed processing with a failure and cannot be further consumed. It can be categorized as a terminal state.

values.name: deleting
values.doc:
The entity is in the process to be deleted. This state is not returned by Azure OpenAI and exposed only for compatibility.
It can be categorized as an active state.

values.name: deleted
values.doc:
The entity has been deleted but may still be referenced by other entities predating the deletion. It can be categorized as a
terminal state.

enums.doc: The state of the file.

values.name: MessageInProgress
values.doc: Event sent when a message moves to `in_progress` status. The data of this event is of type ThreadMessage

values.name: MessageDelta

values.name: MessageCompleted

values.name: MessageIncomplete
values.doc: Event sent before a message is completed. The data of this event is of type ThreadMessage

values.name: Error
values.doc: Event sent when an error occurs, such as an internal server error or a timeout.

values.name: Done
values.doc: Event sent when the stream is done.

enums.doc:
Each event in a server-sent events stream has an `event` and `data` property:

```
event: thread.created
data: {"id": "thread_123", "object": "thread", ...}
```

We emit events whenever a new object is created, transitions to a new state, or is being
streamed in parts (deltas). For example, we emit `thread.run.created` when a new run
is created, `thread.run.completed` when a run completes, and so on. When an Agent chooses
to create a message during a run, we emit a `thread.message.created event`, a
`thread.message.in_progress` event, many `thread.message.delta` events, and finally a
`thread.message.completed` event.

We may add additional events over time, so we recommend handling unknown events gracefully
in your code.

properties.name: temperature
properties.doc:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random,
while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: topP
properties.doc:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass.
So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.doc:
The role of the entity that is creating the message. Allowed values include:
`user`, which indicates the message is sent by an actual user (and should be
used in most cases to represent user-generated messages), and `assistant`,
which indicates the message is generated by the agent (use this value to insert
messages from the agent into the conversation).

The content of the initial message. This may be a basic string (if you only
need text) or an array of typed content blocks (for example, text, image_file,
image_url, and so on).

models.name: Truncation
models.doc:
Controls for how a thread will be truncated prior to the run. Use this to control the initial
context window of the run.

properties.name: type
properties.doc:
The truncation strategy to use for the thread. The default is `auto`. If set to `last_messages`, the thread will
be truncated to the `lastMessages` count most recent messages in the thread. When set to `auto`, messages in the middle of the thread
will be dropped to fit the context length of the model, `max_prompt_tokens`.

properties.name: lastMessages
properties.doc: The number of most recent messages from the thread when constructing the context for the run.

models.name: PersistentAgentsNamedToolChoice
models.doc: Specifies a tool the model should use. Use to force the model to call a specific tool.

properties.name: type
properties.doc: the type of tool. If type is `function`, the function name must be set.

properties.name: function
properties.doc: The name of the function to call

type.name: PersistentAgentsFunctionName
type.doc: The function name that will be used, if using the `function` tool

properties.name: name
properties.doc: The name of the function to call

properties.name: assistantId
properties.doc: The ID of the agent for which the thread should be created.

properties.name: thread
properties.doc: The details used to create the new thread. If no thread is provided, an empty one will be created.

properties.name: OverrideModelName
properties.doc: The overridden model that the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.name: OverrideInstructions
properties.doc: The overridden system instructions the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.name: OverrideTools
properties.doc: The overridden list of enabled tools the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.name: toolResources
properties.doc: Override the tools the agent can use for this run. This is useful for modifying the behavior on a per-run basis

properties.name: stream
properties.doc:
If `true`, returns a stream of events that happen during the Run as server-sent events,
terminating when the Run enters a terminal state with a `data: [DONE]` message.

properties.name: temperature
properties.doc:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output
more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: topP
properties.doc:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model
considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens
comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.name: maxPromptTokens
properties.doc:
The maximum number of prompt tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only
the number of prompt tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of prompt tokens specified,
the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: maxCompletionTokens
properties.doc:
The maximum number of completion tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only
the number of completion tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of completion tokens
specified, the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: truncationStrategy
properties.doc: The strategy to use for dropping messages as the context windows moves forward.

properties.name: toolChoice
properties.doc: Controls whether or not and which tool is called by the model.

properties.name: responseFormat
properties.doc: Specifies the format that the model must output.

properties.name: parallelToolCalls
properties.doc: If `true` functions will run in parallel during tool use.

properties.name: metadata
properties.doc: A set of up to 16 key/value pairs that can be attached to an object, used for storing additional information about that object in a structured format. Keys may be up to 64 characters in length and values may be up to 512 characters in length.

properties.doc: The overridden system instructions that the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.doc:
Additional instructions to append at the end of the instructions for the run. This is useful for modifying the behavior
on a per-run basis without overriding other instructions.

properties.name: additionalMessages
properties.doc: Adds additional messages to the thread before creating the run.

properties.doc: The overridden list of enabled tools that the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.doc: The overridden enabled tool resources that the agent should use to run the thread.

properties.name: stream
properties.doc:
If `true`, returns a stream of events that happen during the Run as server-sent events,
terminating when the Run enters a terminal state with a `data: [DONE]` message.

properties.name: temperature
properties.doc:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output
more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: topP
properties.doc:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model
considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens
comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.name: maxPromptTokens
properties.doc:
The maximum number of prompt tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only
the number of prompt tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of prompt tokens specified,
the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: maxCompletionTokens
properties.doc:
The maximum number of completion tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort
to use only the number of completion tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of
completion tokens specified, the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: truncationStrategy
properties.doc: The strategy to use for dropping messages as the context windows moves forward.

properties.name: toolChoice
properties.doc: Controls whether or not and which tool is called by the model.

properties.name: responseFormat
properties.doc: Specifies the format that the model must output.

properties.name: parallelToolCalls
properties.doc: If `true` functions will run in parallel during tool use.

methods.name: createAgent
methods.doc: Creates a new agent.

operation.name: createAgent
operation.doc: Creates a new agent.

parameters.name: apiVersion
parameters.doc: The API version to use for this operation.

parameters.name: contentType
parameters.doc: Body parameter's content type. Known values are application/json

parameters.name: model
parameters.doc: The ID of the model to use.

parameters.name: name
parameters.doc: The name of the new agent.

parameters.name: description
parameters.doc: The description of the new agent.

parameters.name: instructions
parameters.doc: The system instructions for the new agent to use.

parameters.name: tools
parameters.doc: The collection of tools to enable for the new agent.

parameters.name: toolResources
parameters.doc:
A set of resources that are used by the agent's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter`
tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

parameters.name: temperature
parameters.doc:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random,
while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

parameters.name: topP
parameters.doc:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass.
So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

parameters.name: responseFormat
parameters.doc: The response format of the tool calls used by this agent.

parameters.name: metadata
parameters.doc: A set of up to 16 key/value pairs that can be attached to an object, used for storing additional information about that object in a structured format. Keys may be up to 64 characters in length and values may be up to 512 characters in length.

parameters.name: contentType
parameters.doc: Body parameter's content type. Known values are application/json

operation.name: listAgents
operation.doc: Gets a list of agents that were previously created.

parameters.name: apiVersion
parameters.doc: The API version to use for this operation.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.doc: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

parameters.name: order
parameters.doc: Sort order by the created_at timestamp of the objects. asc for ascending order and desc for descending order.

parameters.name: after
parameters.doc: A cursor for use in pagination. after is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

parameters.name: before
parameters.doc: A cursor for use in pagination. before is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

parameters.doc: The overridden system instructions the agent should use to run the thread.

parameters.name: OverrideTools
parameters.doc: The overridden list of enabled tools the agent should use to run the thread.

parameters.name: toolResources
parameters.doc: Override the tools the agent can use for this run. This is useful for modifying the behavior on a per-run basis

parameters.name: stream
parameters.doc:
If `true`, returns a stream of events that happen during the Run as server-sent events,
terminating when the Run enters a terminal state with a `data: [DONE]` message.

parameters.name: temperature
parameters.doc:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output
more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

parameters.name: topP
parameters.doc:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model
considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens
comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

parameters.name: maxPromptTokens
parameters.doc:
The maximum number of prompt tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only
the number of prompt tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of prompt tokens specified,
the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

parameters.name: maxCompletionTokens
parameters.doc:
The maximum number of completion tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only
the number of completion tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of completion tokens
specified, the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

parameters.name: truncationStrategy
parameters.doc: The strategy to use for dropping messages as the context windows moves forward.

parameters.name: toolChoice
parameters.doc: Controls whether or not and which tool is called by the model.

parameters.name: responseFormat
parameters.doc: Specifies the format that the model must output.

parameters.name: parallelToolCalls
parameters.doc: If `true` functions will run in parallel during tool use.
